When governments actively promote policies to increase the number of women in the paid work force, more women do join the labor force. Policies that empower women to work is good economics. 

Read our staff research: https://t.co/mymQuAhCAB https://t.co/xLlfeOGIUj

Emerging markets account for more than 76% of global coal consumption. Phasing it out can take decades. Green investment, new tech, and supportive policies will help ease the transition for people whose livelihoods depend on coal. #IMFBlog https://t.co/Q5pmKVclRh https://t.co/JtnVfbVBax

Do you have expertise in #macroeconomics, fiscal policy, quantitative techniques, and country surveillance? Use your skills for policy work that impacts the global economy. Apply now for the Mid-Career Program for Experienced Economists. https://t.co/AgQv7E9kkD https://t.co/9y6gltOlFP
What is the IMF's Rapid Financing Instrument (RFI) and how does it help countries during the #COVID19 crisis? https://t.co/KIJtaa2eWt #IMF101 https://t.co/Vd1VJr04cN

Coal accounts for 44% of global CO2 emissions, but phasing it out will be a challenge. Policymakers will face tough questions when considering measures for shifting away from coal. https://t.co/Q5pmKVclRh #IMFBlog https://t.co/dWot1ScIkO

Economic growth provides the basis for overcoming poverty and lifting living standards. But for growth to be sustained and inclusive, its benefits must reach all people. https://t.co/rCz7Ad47rT https://t.co/zE5AsW70WO

Artificial Intelligence could cause a growing divergence between rich and poor countries. Policymakers in developing economies will need to take actions to raise productivity and improve skills. Read more on #IMFBlog: https://t.co/uAlyzmufn4 #AI https://t.co/NvxCRxzSNQ

Can information technology (IT) access, adoption, and education lower unemployment rates? In this video and paper, IMF economists look at how IT can bridge and exacerbate #inequality. https://t.co/hZIn8Wcpra https://t.co/nj2zsYhaDR
What economic measures are governments taking to respond to COVID-19? Key actions taken by 197 economies are listed in our Policy Tracker: https://t.co/GSeyZRWAxk https://t.co/UZhCChnopD

As robots take over work previously performed by people, what is the #futureofjobs? 

@DrDaronAcemoglu and @KGeorgieva discussed how automation could worsen inequality at the 6th Annual Richard Goode Lecture. Watch the replay. https://t.co/XTbV0Ha1M4

Policies that promote #gender equality increase the number of women in the workforce. Gender equality is also one of the 17 @UN Sustainable Development Goals that 193 countries committed to achieve by 2030. #SDGs

Read our latest staff research: https://t.co/iW343rHEKg https://t.co/WpAl4MTsIU

The COVID-19 crisis has highlighted growing inequality across the world. In the latest issue of #FandD, leading progressive economist Heather Boushey (@HBoushey) proposes steps to reduce inequality and transform the US economy. https://t.co/uD47QGbec1 https://t.co/WWbGA73UqL

.@KGeorgieva on avoiding a K-shaped recovery that hurts low-skilled workers:
1. Make taxes progressive without damaging growth
2. Spend on education, health, and social protection
3. Ride the digital revolution to cut red tape on SMEs and make economies more dynamic https://t.co/vyT5kRj1KF

.@KGeorgieva at #SGFintechFest: Just as money crosses borders, so too must our regulatory efforts. International cooperation can facilitate cross-border payments and address spillovers. https://t.co/k0z9O1VCnQ https://t.co/t8Y2QXrO41

The way things stand, we are going to see some countries -#advancedeconomies - will get there much faster than poorer countries will. That should not happen. We should make sure that vaccines are widely available. 
▶️Watch the discussion: https://t.co/ziuOZQmzPC https://t.co/3Y7wfMmA7t

At an @Oxfam panel on #inequality with @Jayati1609, @Gabucher, @jj_saffa & Matthew Martin, IMF Chief Economist @GitaGopinath emphasized: What's top of mind right now is to ensure that there is universal availability of vaccines that can end this pandemic everywhere.
